div1.p: Conquest of Yellow Fever Medal

THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON

PRESIDENT
CAPT. JAMES C. PRYOR
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES NAVY

FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES R. REYNOLDS
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY

SECOND VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES W. COMFORT, JR.
MEDICAL CORPS, CONN. NATIONAL GUARD

EDITOR AND SECRETARY
BRIG. GEN. JEFFERSON R. KEAN
UNITED STATES ARMY, RET.

ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE MILITARY SURGEON
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON, D. C.

THIRD VICE-PRESIDENT
ASST. SURG. GEN. R. C. WILLIAMS
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE

FOURTH VICE-PRESIDENT
COMMANDER WILLIAM S. BAINBRIDGE
M. C. F., UNITED STATES NAVAL RESERVE

ASSISTANT EDITOR
MAJOR EDGAR ERSKINE HUME
MEDICAL CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
3 March, 1931.

In re: Artists draft of proposed Congressional Y.F
medal.
Surgeon General.
MEMORANDUM FOR GENERAL IRELAND.

It would be unfortunate if the inscription on the reverse
of the “Conquest of Yellow Fever” medal should state that it is
given in recognition of “the discovery of the causes of **** yel-
low fever”. The last one of the conclusions of the paper read
by Walter Reed before the Pan American Medical Congress in Havana,
Cuba, February 4, 1901 in which the findings of this Board were
published, is as follows:

“11. While the mode of propagation of yellow fever has now
been definitely determined, the specific cause of this
disease remains to be discovered.”

At the present writing thirty years after these words were written,
the cause still remains to be discovered.
I would suggest that the wording be modified as follows:
AWARDED TO

UNDER THE ACT OF CONGRESS OF FEBRUARY
28, 1929 RECOGNIZING THE HIGH PUBLIC
SERVICE OF MAJOR WALTER REED AND HIS
ASSOCIATES IN DEMONSTRATING THE MANNERS
OF TRANSMITTING AND PREVENTING showing How to Control YELLOW
FEVER.
Jefferson R. Kean
